text:
I grew up in a small town, nestled in the hills of the Appalachian Mountains. I was the youngest of three siblings, and the only girl. My brother, who was two years older than me, was the adventurous one who was always getting into trouble, while my other brother was the studious one who was always studying or reading.

My parents were hardworking folks who had both grown up in the same small town, and they wanted to give their children the same opportunity they had. I can still remember all the nights they stayed up late, working hard to make sure we had food on the table.

As a child, I was very outgoing and social. I loved spending time with my friends and exploring the nearby woods. I was always the one to come up with wild and imaginative ideas for us to do, like sneaking into the old abandoned mine nearby or daring each other to jump off the highest cliff, though I never did. I was always the cautious one, always trying to make sure everybody stayed safe.

One of my favorite activities was exploring the nearby creeks and rivers for crawdads and other creatures. I also loved to fish, and I would often spend entire days sitting on the dock, waiting for a bite. I was also a fan of the outdoors, and I would often go camping with my family. We would pack up the car and head out into the woods, where we would spend the night sleeping under the stars.

I was also a very creative child. I loved to draw and paint, and I would often spend hours creating art pieces. I was also a fan of music, and I would often spend hours playing the guitar and singing along.

As I grew older, I began to take my education more seriously. I studied hard and was eventually accepted into a prestigious university. I was still very outgoing and social, but I was also becoming more conscientious and emotionally stable.

My college years were some of the best of my life. I made lifelong friendships and had some incredible experiences. I graduated with honors, and I decided to pursue a career in the field of psychology.

I now work as a psychologist, and I still have a lot of the same qualities I had as a child. I am still extroverted, conscientious, emotionally stable, and closed to experience. But I have also become more mature and wise, and I use the knowledge and skills I have gained to help my clients.

I still love to explore the outdoors and spend time with my friends and family. I also still love to create art and music, and I often take part in local events and festivals. I couldn’t imagine living anywhere else, and I am thankful for the wonderful childhood I had in the Appalachian Mountains.
prompt:

Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. For example, do you agree that you are someone who likes to spend time with others? Please write a number next to each statement to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with that statement, such as '(a) 1'.
